natural problem:
Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$
natural solution: Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]

draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get

draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);

[/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "let p = (-4, -2); q = (x, y) in sqrt ((fst p - fst q) powr 2 + (snd p - snd q) powr 2) = Min { sqrt ((fst p - fst q') powr 2 + (snd p - snd q') powr 2) | q'. \<exists> x'. q' = (x', f x') }"
shows  "x = 17 / 10" and "y = -1 / 10"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{17}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);
 [/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "let p = (-4, -2); q = (x, y) in sqrt ((fst p - fst q) powr 2 + (snd p - snd q) powr 2) = Min { sqrt ((fst p - fst q') powr 2 + (snd p - snd q') powr 2) | q'. \<exists> x'. q' = (x', f x') }"
shows  "x = 17 / 10" and "y = -1 / 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the point on the line defined by $f(x) = -3x + 5$ that is closest to the point $(-4, -2)$. Express your answer as an ordered pair $(x, y)$. The final answer is $(\frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10})$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = -3 * x + 5"
shows  "(-4,-2) closest (17/10, -1/10)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{17}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);
 [/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = -3 * x + 5"
shows  "(-4,-2) closest (17/10, -1/10)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the point that is closest to the point (17/10, -1/10) on the line defined by the equation y = -3x + 5. The final answer is the point (-4,-2).

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "dist (-4, -2) (x, y) = Min {dist (-4, -2) (a, b) | a b. b = -3 * a + 5}"
shows  "(x, y) = (17 / 10, -1 / 10)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{17}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);
 [/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "dist (-4, -2) (x, y) = Min {dist (-4, -2) (a, b) | a b. b = -3 * a + 5}"
shows  "(x, y) = (17 / 10, -1 / 10)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the point on the line $y = -3x + 5$ that is closest to the point $(-4, -2)$. The coordinates of the point are $(\frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10})$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = -3 * x + 5"
shows  "min_dist x y = (17 / 10, -1 / 10)"
where "min_dist x y = dist (x, y) (-4, -2)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{17}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);
 [/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = -3 * x + 5"
shows  "min_dist x y = (17 / 10, -1 / 10)"
where "min_dist x y = dist (x, y) (-4, -2)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given the line equation $y = -3x + 5$, find the point on the line that is closest to the point (-4, -2). The final answer is $(\frac{17}{10}, \frac{-1}{10})$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = -3 * x + 5"
shows  "\<exists>x y. (x, y) = (17 / 10, -1 / 10)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{17}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);
 [/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = -3 * x + 5"
shows  "\<exists>x y. (x, y) = (17 / 10, -1 / 10)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find a pair of real numbers (x, y) that satisfy the equation y = -3x + 5. The final answer is (17/10, -1/10).

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "\<exists> x y. (x - -4)\<^sup>2 + (f x - -2)\<^sup>2 = (y - -4)\<^sup>2 + (f y - -2)\<^sup>2 \<and> (x - -4)\<^sup>2 + (f x - -2)\<^sup>2 \<le> (z - -4)\<^sup>2 + (f z - -2)\<^sup>2 \<forall> z"
shows  "x = 17 / 10 \<and> y = -1 / 10"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{17}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);
 [/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "\<exists> x y. (x - -4)\<^sup>2 + (f x - -2)\<^sup>2 = (y - -4)\<^sup>2 + (f y - -2)\<^sup>2 \<and> (x - -4)\<^sup>2 + (f x - -2)\<^sup>2 \<le> (z - -4)\<^sup>2 + (f z - -2)\<^sup>2 \<forall> z"
shows  "x = 17 / 10 \<and> y = -1 / 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given that $f(x) = -3x + 5$, find the values of $x$ and $y$ such that the sum of the squares of $x+4$ and $f(x)+2$ is equal to the sum of the squares of $y+4$ and $f(y)+2$, and this sum is less than or equal to the sum of the squares of $z+4$ and $f(z)+2$ for all possible values of $z$. The final answer is $x = \frac{17}{10}$ and $y = \frac{-1}{10}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. sqrt ((x + 4) powr 2 + (f x + 2) powr 2) = min ((x + 4) powr 2 + (f x + 2) powr 2)"
shows  "x = 17 / 10 \<and> y = -1 / 10"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{17}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);
 [/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. sqrt ((x + 4) powr 2 + (f x + 2) powr 2) = min ((x + 4) powr 2 + (f x + 2) powr 2)"
shows  "x = 17 / 10 \<and> y = -1 / 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given the function $f(x) = -3x + 5$, find the values of $x$ and $y$ such that the square root of the sum of the squares of $x + 4$ and $f(x) + 2$ is equal to the smallest value of the sum of the squares of $x + 4$ and $f(x) + 2$. The final answer is $x = \frac{17}{10}$ and $y = -\frac{1}{10}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "(-4, -2) \<in> closest_point_on_line f"
shows  "closest_point_on_line f = (17/10, -1/10)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{17}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);
 [/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "(-4, -2) \<in> closest_point_on_line f"
shows  "closest_point_on_line f = (17/10, -1/10)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given the function $f(x) = -3x + 5$, find the point on the graph of this function that is closest to the point (-4, -2). The answer is the point (17/10, -1/10).

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "(-4, -2) \<in> {(x, f x) | x. x \<in> UNIV}"
and h2 : "\<forall> x' y'. (-4, -2) \<in> {(x', f x') | x'. x' \<in> UNIV} \<longrightarrow> dist (x, y) (-4, -2) \<le> dist (x', y') (-4, -2)"
shows  "x = 17 / 10" and "y = -1 / 10"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{17}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);
 [/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "(-4, -2) \<in> {(x, f x) | x. x \<in> UNIV}"
and h2 : "\<forall> x' y'. (-4, -2) \<in> {(x', f x') | x'. x' \<in> UNIV} \<longrightarrow> dist (x, y) (-4, -2) \<le> dist (x', y') (-4, -2)"
shows  "x = 17 / 10" and "y = -1 / 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider a function $f(x) = -3x + 5$. The point $(-4, -2)$ belongs to the graph of this function. Find the coordinates $(x, y)$ of the point on the graph of $f(x)$ that is closest to $(-4, -2)$. The final answer is $x = \frac{17}{10}$ and $y = -\frac{1}{10}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "dist (x, y) (-4, -2) = min_dist (f x) (-4, -2)"
shows  "x = 17 / 10 \<and> y = -1 / 10"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = -3x + 5\]that is closest to the point $(-4,-2).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(0,5)$ and $(1,2)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$(1,2)$", D, E); [/asy] The vector going from $(0,5)$ to $(-4,-2)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ -7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{17}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, C, D, P, V; A = ((5 + 10)/3, -10); B = ((5 - 10)/3, 10); V = (-4,-2); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; C = (0,5); D = (1,2); draw((-10,0)--(10,0)); draw((0,-10)--(0,10));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); dot("$(-4,-2)$", V, SW); dot("$(0,5)$", C, E); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NE);
 [/asy] Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{51}{10} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{17}{10} \\ -\frac{1}{10} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(-4,-2)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{17}{10}, -\frac{1}{10} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = -3 * x + 5"
and h1 : "dist (x, y) (-4, -2) = min_dist (f x) (-4, -2)"
shows  "x = 17 / 10 \<and> y = -1 / 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given the function $f(x) = -3x + 5$, find the values of $x$ and $y$ such that the distance between the point $(x, y)$ and the point $(-4, -2)$ is equal to the minimum distance from $f(x)$ to the point $(-4, -2)$. The solution is $x = \frac{17}{10}$ and $y = -\frac{1}{10}$.
